title: Wednesday, 24th October 2018
bodyHTML:
11:10 am
BE11:10am

A very good morning to every single one of you, except the Moncler PR department.

Manxish Morning all
Excel Developer Hi,
Blank canvas good morning everyone
Markkus morning
BE11:11am

Dear Bryce,

I hope this email finds you well.

I am writing to you on behalf of Moncler's Press Office and more specifically about the article released yesterday "Stocks to watch: AMS, HSBC, Prada, Bayer, CYBG, Atos, Enel".

We have noticed that Moncler is described as a "skiwear maker", while Moncler has currently consolidated its position as a worldwide luxury outerwear brand leader. The Group has become a proper "global luxury brand".

Would it be possible for you to amend the subject wording "skiwear maker" into "global luxury brand" and/or to consider this from now?

Looking forward to receiving your kind feedback, thank you very much for your kind attention.

Soundbuy Morning
VV75 morning

Got that? Moncler, the global luxury brand. They're not just puffy jackets any more.

Ghazali Morning
Manxish I would also like to be called a Global Luxury Brand from now on. thank you all

Blank canvas GLBs for everyone

BE11:22am

Metro bank 3Q18 underlying PBT of £15.1m is up 7% QoQ although lower than our forecasts of £17.9m due to lower revenues and higher costs. Revenues increased by 7% QoQ to £105m driven by loan growth of 9% to £13.1bn with customer net interest margin increasing by 1bp to 2.21% (PGe 2.27%). Within this Metro recorded a further gain of £4.0m on sale of securities. Deposits in the quarter increased by 8% to £14.8bn with a loan-to-deposit ratio rising by 2ppt QoQ to 89%. The cost of deposit increased by 2bp to 61bp. Credit quality
deteriorated slightly in 3Q18 by 1bp QoQ to 7bp. CET1 ratio increased by 3ppt QoQ to 15.7% (PGe 15.5%) following the £303m capital increase in July 2018.
Overall, underlying PBT was a 16% miss on our estimates driven by both lower revenues due to lower loan growth and NIM than our expectations. Although Metro Bank is making progress towards management’s targets, the quarterly results progress is rather uneven and at FY2018E P/TBV of 1.9 for RoE of 3.6% we believe that the future returns potential is more than discounted in the current share price.

Excel Developer @Lemmy: Christ knows. What I do know is the current situation in untenable.
TonaldDrump Anyone believe that a 2nd vote would end with remain?
chad_john Nope

consensus is too optimistic on margin. Metro has seen earnings
downgrades in Q1 and Q2 and we now expect Q3 which we expect is
unhelpful for sentiment.

BE11:27am

Metro really seems to be the stock that (UK) investors love to hate, yet the facts continue to sit uncomfortably with the bears’ narrative. Deposit growth continues to accelerate, +£1.1bn QoQ to £14.8bn. Importantly, this is led by cheap/sticky current account and instant access savings accounts (see Fig 3, page 3), which, taken together, contributed 85% of the QoQ deposit growth. As a consequence, and benefitting from a 0.25% base rate rise in August, Metro’s cost of deposits fell below base rate for the first time, up just 2bps QoQ to 61bps.

Tom Dalgleish Didnt Giggs spill out a different way?
BE11:27am

Growth has (at least for now) fallen out of fashion, with significant de-ratings for businesses valued on the basis of expectations of such growth. We see Metro Bank as a primary example (and victim) of this new phenomenon. Be that as it may, today’s Q3 IMS has delivered pretty much what we have come to expect from Metro; accelerating loan growth driving improving operational leverage. We expect weakness today but, for us, the outlook remains robust.

BE11:32am

A broadly positive 1H, with good underlying profit growth in the core Aviation and Energy divisions partially offset by a loss in Rail. Passenger growth is being delivered at London Southend Airport (LSA, +37%) supported by the accelerated investment in the Flybe franchise operations. These operations are being withdrawn in February 2020 following agreements with easyJet and Ryanair to expand operations, with the stepchange
partnership with Ryanair enhancing our confidence in the attainment of the 5m passenger target by 2022. Elsewhere tonnes supplied and profitability are increasing in Energy despite further delays in plant commissioning, and cash is being realised from asset sales in Infrastructure. Whilst Rail reported a loss, we view this as a one-off and expect an improved performance in 2H. We have updated forecasts for the first time since January, cutting our FY19E/FY20E EBITDA estimates by 26/27% but note our assumptions for the key Aviation and Energy divisions are broadly unchanged. We remain Buyers with our sum-of-the-parts derived target price moving to 268p. We continue to see significant potential for medium-term value creation, with the group's non-operating assets providing multi-year visibility on the attractive 18p p.a. dividend yielding over 8%.

rw42 If anything i'd say they should change the rules for future referendums to require a bigger margin - 52:48% sounds ridiculous as a mandate to change something that either way half the country will be unhappy with!

Cineworld Group PLC (CINE:LSE): Last: 272.20, down 6.4 (-2.30%), High: 272.40, Low: 265.80, Volume: 2.25m
BE11:44am

Which is on Barclays, and is an admirably straightforward note.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

US interest rates up, earnings down. That's the upshot.

BE11:46am

Trading is strong, but US interest rates are rising – rating downgraded to EW: We believe that investors in Cineworld face a dilemma. Trading is currently very strong in the US and there may be upside to Regal synergies of $100m. However, US interest rates are rising, all of Cineworld's debt is at floating rates (c80% is US based), and leverage is relatively high (FY19 Net Debt/EBITDA is 3.2x). CINE is a consensual "Buy" among sell side analysts (10 out of 12 Buy ratings, source: Bloomberg), yet we believe that consensus forecasts do not reflect the risk of rising rates. In this report we attempt to factor in US rate rises in line with Barclays' economics forecasts. Whilst our FY19 EBITDA is in line with Bloomberg consensus, our FY19 PBT is 8% below consensus. A clear upside risk is that the company trades more strongly than we expect, but we believe that the investment debate is more balanced now, and stronger trading could be offset by higher interest costs. Accordingly, we downgrade to EW from OW and trim our PT to 305p. We use an EV/EBITDA of 8x for Regal (unchanged), and use 10.5x vs 11x previously for UK and CEE & Israel given weaker recent performance.

BE11:46am

Forecasts moved to US dollars: EBITDA upgrades, PBT downgrades, FCF trimmed: Relative to our previous implied US dollar forecasts, we upgrade FY19 EBITDA by 4% (reflects accounting change to deferred revenue) but downgrade PBT and EPS by c7%, as we increase our interest cost forecasts. This partly reflects the non-cash interest costs flagged by the company (eg, deferred revenue interest cost, offsetting the EBITDA boost), but also reflects our economists' forecasts that Fed Funds will rise by 100bps over the next 12 months. We assume no change in European rates (c20% of debt), and there is a mitigating factor from the 'margin ratchet', which means the margin paid on the term loan falls by 25bps if Debt/EBITDA falls below 3.5x. Overall, we assume a 55bps rise in our FY19 interest coupon vs FY18.

BE11:53am

The company’s Board now guides to adjustments to the above requiring a profit reduction of c£10m to this year’s profitability, Yü Group is now guided to make a loss for the current year to December 2018. The Board is confident of achieving profitability for FY2019F. We note the confirmation that the company has already booked contracted revenues for FY2019F of £67m. Yü’ retains a strong balance sheet with net cash reserves of c£11.5m as at end September.

The accounting issues stem from an assessment of historic ‘aged accrued income balances’ amounting to c£4.3m (as at end June 2018, Interim Results), that this amount is unlikely to be recoverable. In respect of trade debtors, the Board has concluded that the level of bad debt provisioning has been insufficient (this in addition to the adoption of IFRS9 – Financial Instruments, Recognition & Measurement); we assess this to be a c£5.7m charge to the historic accounts. These two factors combined, with a requirement of greater provisioning, indicate that the gross margin achievable in future is likely to be at a lower level. The company also takes account of gross margin compression from competitive market conditions in its analysis.

Clearly, this news comes as a disappointment, we look forward to a resumption of profitability next year with continued revenue growth. In the interim, whilst we assess the position for FY2018F and beyond, we temporarily withdraw our current forecasts. We expect to post revised expectations shortly post discussion with the management team.

Blank canvas thanks for babcock. have a good day BE
BE12:06pm

Liberum -- which seems to be the go-to broker for knocking down sort reports given their recent work in RPC -- said this about the ST story

BE12:07pm

A note from Boatman Capital has raised five concerns about Babcock. We
believe that there is nothing new in the note and address each concern in
turn. 1) Delays on the construction of the Devonport dry dock will not result
in a £100m hit to Babcock. 2) There have been delays on the Warrior
programme, but Babcock is a relatively small sub-contractor. 3) Appledore
is running out of work and may need to be restructured, and this could
result in a small exceptional but no material impact on ongoing estimates.
4) We do not see Babcock as having a particularly challenged relationship
with the MoD. 5) Increased pricing pressure from the Single Source
Regulators Office (SSRO) is an old argument and we believe it is
manageable. Buy, price target of 1100p, CY 19 P/E of 7.1x.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

Delays on the construction of the Devonport dry dock will not result in a
£100m hit to Babcock
A new dry dock is being commissioned by the MoD at Babcock’s facility at Devonport to provide a dry
dock for the Dreadnaught and Astute submarines. The MoD has chosen to delay the commissioning.
Babcock may bid the work, with a partner, when it comes to market, but is not responsible for any
delays.
There have been delays on the Warrior programme, but Babcock is a relatively
small sub-contractor
At its Q2 results, Lockheed took a $65m impairment for performance issues on its Warrior Capability
Sustainment Program (CSP). Babcock is a sub-contractor and management claims that Babcock is
only responsible for c.10% of the contact value. We therefore see a small adverse effect as possible.
Appledore is running out of work and may need to be restructured, and this
could result in a small exceptional but no material impact on ongoing
estimates
As we wrote last week, Babcock has failed to secure a contract to build an Offshore Patrol Vessel
(OPV) for the Maltese Navy. The four OPVs for the Irish navy are substantially complete. There is a
limited near term pipe-line of work, as Military Afloat Reach and Sustainability (MARS) will be built in
South Korea and Babcock is unlikely to win work on the Type 31e. It may be necessary to close the
yard, which could result in a £20m exceptional charge, due to onerous leases etc, although staff are
already being transferred to Devonport. We expect no material ongoing impact since Appledore only
generated £14m of sales in FY 2018.

BE12:07pm

We do not see Babcock as having a particularly challenged relationship with
the MoD
There are inevitable tensions between the MoD and its key suppliers. However, we believe that there
are no specific tensions around Devonport, as above. Only last month, Babcock announced that
Marine had secured a five year Ship Naval Design Partnering (NDP) contract with the Ministry of
Defence (MOD) with options for extension and Land had been awarded additional contracts worth
c.£120 million with the Ministry of Defence to maintain equipment as part of the DSG contract.
Increased pricing pressure from the Single Source Regulators Office (SSRO) is
an old argument and we believe it is manageable
SSRO has been used for 4 years, and while the revenues that it applies to could increase from
£100m to £800m, as Maritime Support delivery Framework (MSDF) falls under it in 2020, back-testing
it on other programs (like DSG and HMS Valliant) suggests that margins can actually be marginally
higher under SSRO. Management has consistently said that Babcock can achieve a 10% margin on
SSRO through incentive payments. Technology and overseas are also important contributors to the
Marine division margin.
Buy, price target of 1100p, CY 19 P/E of 7.1x
A CY 2019 P/E of 7.1x is a c.40% discount to the sector average. Babcock also has an above
average CY 2019 FCF yield of 10.0%. Our target price of 1100p is based on a sum of the parts. BUY.

BE12:08pm

Apologies for over-quoting. But I figure it was old.
